text: [Music]
yes in theory yes but I think first of
all we should remind ourselves that
against the
background in India there was quite a
sustained campaign of violence against
the British uh but we didn't have a
gandai figure we didn't we didn't have
such a figure we didn't have a bishop 2u
we didn't have a Martin Luther King On
My Le good and brave people who who did
proclaim the good news uh the fact
is the history of
Ireland uh is one in which the physical
Force tradition is quite strong and
secondly uh at at the time of of uh
what's called trouble or
troubles uh the military response has
almost been the first reaction by the
British state so so whether it was
agrarian struggle whether it was
economic struggle or social emancipation
or whether it was Independence or
Liberation struggle uh the British
cracked down quite viciously and given
the AR psychic and given our own history
uh the physical Force tendency was
always in the in in the ascendancy so
you know as you get older you reflecting
on on things and you see things from a a
life experience and from a different
uh
perspective uh I do think that uh armed
actions were and I defended them at the
time were
justifiable in the context in which they
occurred I don't agree with everything
that happened in fact I strongly
disagree and disapprove of some of the
things that uh happened but I
think the core of what we put together
in this process was to develop an
alternative to Armed action so it it
wasn't a matter of condemning or
denouncing or uh marginalizing the
people who used physical force it was a
matter of sense them look you don't have
to do that because here here's a
different way to do it but that
meant uh other pillars of society
including governments that meant the
International Community taking their
weight of the responsibility and and
showing that politics could actually
work because up onto that point politics
had not worked
all
